DOC.HEAD: Romanians Bury Their `Heroes Of The Revolution'
With PM-Romania, Bjt
LaserPhoto BUCH6
DOC.TEXT: At graveside, a yellow bath towel knotted around a rough pine cross and a spray of white chrysanthemums scrounged in a city where even bread is scarce were among tributes to heroes of the revolution. A procession of sobbing families Tuesday accompanied makeshift coffins to a field of 200 freshly dug graves in southern Bucharest. One coffin was for 14-year-old Silviu Minca, whose friends said he was killed when the nation's hated security police called to them from a window and opened fire when they approached. The security police have killed hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people in in their armed resistance to the uprising that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu. Officials at Belo cemetery believe 300 to 400 people killed in fighting during the past five days will have to be buried, but perhaps hundreds more are believed hidden in secret graves dug by Ceausescu's men before he was overthrown. By a pine cross marked ``first hero,'' a veteran gravedigger named Nicolae Abag wept along with the mourners. ``This is so, so much,'' he said. ``I have not cried here since the earth moved in 1977,'' the year of the earthquake in which almost 2,000 people were killed. At the next grave, people mourned Nicisor Paunoiu, an elevator mechanic who responded when the radio station appealed for help because it was attacked by the Securitate, the security police. Paunoiu and three friends stormed a Securitate stronghold unarmed. Three of them were cut down by automatic weapons fire. He left a son and a daughter who was married three weeks ago. Farther down, there was the student Dan Adrian Urucu, who went to protect the TV station. He joined 3,000 others in a human shield between harassing Ceausescu loyalists and army men protecting the 13-story TV building. Urucu, 21, was shot in the back. ``His death was for all of us, for our freedom,'' student Ileana Nita said as she stood by Urucu's grave. ``It was a sacrifice we must appreciate. We have to learn what it means to be free and what that is worth.'' Bits of food, round bread rings and bath towels adorned many of the graves, symbols from an ancient tradition of offering things to the dead they may need in the afterlife. Boughs from Christmas trees with long, yellow candles burning were left on many graves and there were photographs of smiling young faces tacked to crosses. The Romanian news agency Agerpress said a monument would be erected at the cemetery to pay tribute the revolution's dead for ``their pure sacrifice for Romania's freedom.''
